item.title: Running #chatmail servers is <2h effort per month, according to an ad-hoc poll with 10 operators responding. Some have 10Ks of #deltachat users. Typically 300MB ram is used and max 60gb disc space per server. And all interoperate safely based on high security standards (DKIM and TLS enforced, and only no-metadata #openpgp encrypted messages allowed) .... with typically 0.5 secs end-to-end delivery. Who said again that email is insecure, cumbersome and slow? :) Screenshot of 10 chatmail operators polled about "admin hours spent last month" with two saying "0 hours" and 8 saying "less than 2 hours" with none spending more.

Maybe the secret why the #deltachat project with "just" a dozen active contributors succeeds in delivering cross-platform apps, instigating the #chatmail server network and spearheading the #webxdc app paradigm, lies in asking the right questions: - Is it really needed? - Can we not do it? - Is there a simpler way that requires less changes? - What is the interesting next impl step that is already interesting itself for users, without requiring first completing a big refactoring project?

We are well aware of the increasing risk of infiltration of our software development, especially as we offer a very high level of privacy. Core Delta contributors know each other personally from many physical week-long gatherings even if we are typically remotely collaborating across thousands of kilometers. Are we immune to infiltration, corruption or bad-faith PRs to our repositories? No, but we value minimalism, work in public and engage with specialists for analysis and audits. #security

Did you know that #deltachat does not need and does not use key servers? Most other messengers (wa/signal/matrix/threema/...) actually operate or incorporate a cryptographic key server, managing the cryptographic identities of all users. Delta Chat uses decentralized protocols for key management avoiding a central storage of identities. The SecureJoin protocol is the key (sic!) innovation and was independently analyzed by ETH ZÃ¼rich researchers earlier this year .... https://delta.chat/en/2024-03-25-crypto-analysis-securejoin

Some complain about the lack of PFS but there are good reasons for not employing it and we have a well working "guaranteed end-to-end encryption" system. Others complain about the lack of some Telegram features but Durov's project keep data of a. biIllion users in cleartext. When shit hits the fan, we want delta chat apps to be mass-ready, provide secure and reliable private messaging service even in authoritarian environments. Easier said than done. Lots of details to care for.

Delta Chat collabs are carefully cooking new major features by a series of discussion/coding steps with roughly this recipe mix: - one part: discussing a feature and its step wise implementation - three parts: how does it square with usability outcomes (eg avoiding failure modes in the dialogue trees; who really needs this? what do they say themselves?) - one part: how it can be attacked? Focus on real security outcomes. - two parts: how can we avoid maintenance monsters for future us?

As you know, governmental forces within the EU, the US, the UK, Russia and others are in a hot competition on who gets to be the first to subvert end-to-end encryption. A few days ago, we got another letter from Roskomnadzor, the #russia telco authority, to help them get at user data or metadata for #deltachat users. But there is no central registry of e-mail addresses, messages or decryption keys. So we declined. Sorry, not sorry. A letter from merlinux GmbH to ROSKOMNADZOR Russian Federal Service for Supervision in the Sphere of Telecom, Information Technologies and Mass Communications per e-mail: 97-fz@rkn.gov.ru Freiburg, June 13th 2024 Your request for registration of Delta Chat regarding provided services in Russia Dear Sirs and Madams, on June 11th 2024 we received your request by e-mail to delta@merlinux.eu to register for provided messaging services in Russia for the application Delta Chat whose developments we indeed facilitate and distribute to app stores and many platforms. If we understand your request correctly, you also requested access to decryption keys and access to user data. However, Delta Chat is an e-mail application which lets users choose their e-mail providers at their own discretion. There is no central registry of e-mail addresses and we have no access to message contents, let alone decryption keys which only exist on user devices. We therefore kindly request that you strike us from your list of service providers. best regards and thanks, holger krekel, managing director, merlinux GmbH
